title: working from my remote Github, how do I create a new branch and then clone it?

parts: working from my remote Github, how do I create a new branch and then clone it?

If you already have the repo on your machine and it’s connected to your GitHub remote (usually called `origin`), the usual flow is:

## 1) Create a new branch locally
From your repo directory:

```bash
git status
git fetch origin
git switch -c my-new-branch
```

(Older equivalent: `git checkout -b my-new-branch`.)

## 2) Push the new branch to GitHub (so it exists on the remote)
```bash
git push -u origin my-new-branch
```

The `-u` sets the upstream so future `git push` / `git pull` work without extra arguments.

---

## 3) “Clone it” (get that branch on another machine / fresh folder)

### Option A (most common): normal clone, then checkout the branch
```bash
git clone <REPO_URL>
cd <repo-folder>
git switch my-new-branch
```

If `git switch my-new-branch` complains the branch doesn’t exist locally yet, do:
```bash
git fetch origin
git switch -c my-new-branch --track origin/my-new-branch
```

### Option B: clone *only* that branch
This only works if the branch already exists on GitHub (step 2 done):

```bash
git clone -b my-new-branch --single-branch <REPO_URL>
```

---

If you tell me what you mean by “working from my remote Github” (do you already have a local clone, or are you starting from scratch?), I can tailor the exact commands to your situation.
starting from scrtach, create a new branch in my existing remote repository, and then clone that branch onto my local WSL

You can’t create a *new* branch on a remote GitHub repo using only `git` **without** having some local Git repo/ref to base it on. So from “scratch” you have two practical options:

## Option A (recommended): Create the branch on GitHub first, then clone that branch in WSL

### A1) Create the branch on GitHub (web UI)
1. Open your repo on GitHub in a browser.
2. Click the branch dropdown (it usually says `main` or `master`).
3. Type your new branch name (e.g. `feature/wsl-setup`).
4. Choose **“Create branch: feature/wsl-setup from ‘main’”** (or whatever base branch you want).

Now the branch exists on the remote.

### A2) Clone *that branch* onto WSL
In WSL:

```bash
cd ~
git clone -b feature/wsl-setup --single-branch https://github.com/OWNER/REPO.git
cd REPO
```

Check you’re on the right branch:

```bash
git branch --show-current
git remote -v
```

If your repo is private and HTTPS prompts are annoying, consider using SSH instead:

```bash
git clone -b feature/wsl-setup --single-branch git@github.com:OWNER/REPO.git
```

---

## Option B: Clone first (default branch), then create the new branch and push it
This is the standard Git workflow when you don’t want to use the GitHub UI.

```bash
cd ~
git clone https://github.com/OWNER/REPO.git
cd REPO
git switch -c feature/wsl-setup
git push -u origin feature/wsl-setup
```

That leaves you with the branch created on GitHub and your WSL working copy already on it.

---

If you tell me your repo URL format (HTTPS or SSH) and what your default branch is (`main` vs `master`), I can plug in the exact commands with the right names.
